key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse was found not guilty on all charges related to the shootings of Joseph Rosenbaum and Anthony Huber.
The incident occurred on August 25, 2020, during a volatile protest in Kenosha, Wisconsin, over a police shooting.
Rittenhouse, then 17, carried a semiautomatic rifle to the protest and fired eight shots.
Rosenbaum, 36, and Huber, 26, were killed by Rittenhouse, while a third man was injured.
The opinion piece argues against bringing firearms to protests, citing the dangers highlighted by the Rittenhouse case.
Despite the legal outcome, the article raises concerns about America's culture of displaying firearms at public protests.
The dismissal of a lesser charge of underage teen carrying a rifle by the trial's judge is mentioned, to argue that it's not just a legal or Second Amendment issue.
The author doubts whether the Rittenhouse case will lead to a lesson on the dangers of mixing firearms and angry protests.
The deaths of Rosenbaum and Huber are highlighted as a tragic outcome of Rittenhouse's decision to attend the protest armed.
The article serves as a critique of America's love for firearms, especially at protests.
